text: this is Mac William bishop for DealBook
at the new york times it has been called
the biggest insider trading trial in a
generation one of Wall Street's most
successful investors will appear in
federal court beginning March eighth to
face charges that he made more than 45
million dollars trading on illegal stock
tips well it's going to be a landmark
case as far as the Justice Department is
concerned right now there's a big
perception on Main Street that Wall
Street is in fact rigged and that
privileged have advantages over those
who do not have the wealth and power as
mr. rajaratnam has so is of great
significance the Justice Department to
send a message that those folks are not
above the law Raj Rajaratnam co-founded
the hedge fund galleon group in the
insider trading case against him
prosecutors have used investigative
tactics once reserved for organized
crime and narcotics trafficking the use
of wiretaps has traditionally been
within the realm of drug enforcement
actions to use it in the white collar
context is indeed unusual and olive oil
I think it sets the tone for white
collar investigations going forward the
government's case against mr. rajaratnam
has cast a spotlight on the hedge fund
industry which has become one of the
most powerful forces on Wall Street it
will also bring a number of high-profile
finance executives to the stand this
could potentially include even Lloyd
Blankfein the chief executive of Goldman
Sachs in addition to a wealth of
recorded conversations obtained through
wiretaps the case will also hinge on
testimony from mr. rajaratnam erstwhile
co-conspirators many of them have
already pleaded guilty and are
cooperating with prosecutors in a case
like this if a person was to fight the
charges and be found guilty in many
cases they would easily be facing
between 10 and 20 years in prison if
they plead guilty and if they cooperate
they can often get that sentence down to
somewhere between two years three years
four years something like that depending
on the the involvement that they had and
depending on how much they cooperate
with the government mr. rajaratnam
defense team is expected to focus on the
mosaic theory of investing but former
prosecutors think that mr. rajaratnam
will have a hard time convincing a jury
that he was just a very savvy investor
under the most
theory what hedge funds do is they
collect as much information as possible
and that includes private or non-public
information but that private non-public
information can't be material that is it
can't be really important essentially
and so what the government is going to
say is this private non-public
information that galleon was trading on
was material that is it was would have
been important to a reasonable investor
and what Raj Rajaratnam is going to say
is that it was not material but that to
him because he knew so much and had so
much other information he was able to
divine its importance but the reasonable
investor in his situation wouldn't have
been and therefore he's going to seek an
acquittal the case is also a test for
the US government's ability to bring
white-collar criminals to justice the US
Attorney leading the case Preet Bharara
has said bet insider trading is rampant
on Wall Street the rajaratnam trial is
an important part of the government's
efforts to deter financial crime now the
reality of the situation is an insider
trading is never going to go away
however it's important that the
government do cases like this from time
to time to let people on Wall Street
know that they're out there and if they
catch you you know you're going to be
severely punished so I think that's
really the lesson in this case but for
mr. rajaratnam and the host of lawyers
on the prosecution and defense the only
issue that will matter is that of guilt
versus innocence this is Mack William
bishop for DealBook at the New York
Times
you
you
